titleStmt.title: Stability and l 1 Gain Analysis of Boolean Networks with Markovian Jump Parameters

analytic.title: Stability and l 1 Gain Analysis of Boolean Networks with Markovian Jump Parameters

biblStruct.note: This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication. Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TAC.2017.2679903, IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper presents some results on stability and l 1 gain analysis of Boolean networks with Markovian jump parameters. A necessary and sufficient condition for global stability of the concerned Boolean networks is given in terms of linear programming by utilizing the semi-tensor product of matrices and some properties of linear positive systems. Then the definition of Lyapunov function for stochastic Boolean networks is presented and a Lyapunov theorem is derived. Moreover, an l 1 gain problem for stochastic Boolean networks with external disturbances is formulated and solved by a sufficient condition. Examples are shown to illustrate the effectiveness of the obtained results.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: Since Boolean networks (BNs) were first applied to model and describe genetic regulatory networks in 1969 [1], much attention has been drawn to the study and applications of BNs [2]- [7]. The dynamics of this kind of models are much simpler and more effective to express the genetic variables, which are quantified as "1" and "0" to stand for expressed and unexpressed states, respectively. Unfortunately, there were no systematic and effective tools that analyze and synthesize this kind of models until the semi-tensor product (STP) of matrices was proposed by Cheng and his colleagues [8], [9]. Based on the new algebraic method, a multitude of interesting problems for BNs, such as controllability and observability [10]- [15], fixed points and limit cycles [16], [17], stability and stabilization [18], [19], optimal control [20]- [23], have been extensively addressed.

It should be noted that each gene of a genetic regulatory network may be updated according to one of several possible rules at each discrete time. A quintessential example is the bacteriophage λ, which has two different behaviors, lysis and lysogeny. Additionally, an asynchronous BN can be redescribed as a group of BNs, in which just one BN is active at each time [24]. These can be regarded as the switching phenomenon in BNs. The reachability, controllability and stability have been well studied for deterministic switching BNs in [25], [26]. When the switching signal between two different constituent BNs is regulated by a probability structure, probabilistic BNs may have advantage to model rule-based properties and tackle existing uncertainties. Many interesting problems, including stability analysis, have been investigated [27]- [30]. Since genetic regulatory networks are structured by networks of regulatory interactions between DNA, RNA, and proteins in the expression of other genes, a series of molecular processes are always involved in cells subject to some intrinsic fluctuations and extrinsic perturbations so that gene expression is considered as a stochastic process. Markov chains have been widely used to model gene networks [31], [32]. In fact, probabilistic BNs [33] can be regarded as a special class of Markov Min Meng, Lu Liu and Gang Feng are with the Department of Mechanical and Biomedical Engineering, City University of Hong Kong, Kowloon, Hong Kong. (e-mail: mengminmath@gmail.com; luliu45@cityu.edu.hk; megfeng@cityu.edu.hk).

The work described in this paper was supported by the Research Grants Council of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China under Project CityU/11209514. chains [34]. Besides, in complex multicellular organisms, the rules of updates at each step of a particular gene may be quite different and it has been observed that transitions between states in a gene network occur randomly. A concrete example is the genetic toggle switch in a simple genetic circuit, where two proteins negatively regulate the synthesis of each other. With spontaneous transitions, the updates of the two proteins can be described by stochastic processes. BNs with Markovian jump parameters, or equivalently Markovian switching BNs, are thus suitable to model some gene expression with stochastic switching factors. This kind of BNs can be considered as an extension of deterministic switching BNs and probabilistic BNs. Nevertheless, to our best knowledge, there are few papers concerning BNs with Markovian jump parameters. In [35], a necessary and sufficient condition depending on the transition matrix and time is developed for the stochastic stability of BNs under any Markovian jump signal. However, the computation is very complex and thus less desirable in practice.

On one hand, stability analysis for BNs with Markovian jump parameters enables us to determine whether a genetic network in the presence of stochastic switching signals will evolve into a desired state corresponding to a healthy and beneficial target. On the other hand, it is well known that there are often intracellular and extracellular noises existing in all components in cells due to random births and deaths of individual molecules and environment fluctuations [36]. Such noises, regarded as disturbances, may affect the dynamics of the whole biological system, degrade the system performance and even destroy the stability of the concerned system. Thus, it is desirable to evaluate the impact of disturbances on BNs, which motivates our study in this paper.

In this paper, stability and l1 gain of BNs with Markovian jump parameters are analyzed via the tool of STP of matrices. A necessary and sufficient condition in a linear programming form for such BNs is derived based on some results of linear positive systems. This condition can be regarded as a Lyapunov stability criterion by designing a stochastic Lyapunov function. Motivated by the optimal control problem for BNs [20]- [23] and the payoff function of a player in a game [37], an l1 gain in a stochastic form for BNs with Markovian jump parameters is defined. Then, the l1 gain problem is formulated and solved by a sufficient condition established by constructing a Lyapunov function. The main contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows. First, the necessary and sufficient condition for global stability of Markovian switching BNs, which is dependent on the Markovian jump parameters, is more practical than that in [35]. Second, the effect of external disturbances on stochastic BNs is quantified by an l1 gain for the first time. Finally, the results in this paper are more general and can include some existing works, for instance [38], [39], as special cases.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces some necessary preliminaries of STP and system description. The global stability and l1 gain analysis of stochastic BNs are investigated in Sections III and IV, respectively. Section V gives illustrative examples to show the effectiveness of the obtained results, which is followed by a brief conclusion in Section VI.
Notations: Denote by N, R n and Mm×n the sets of nonnegative integers, n-dimensional column vectors and m × n real matrices, respectively. The i-th column of identity matrix In is defined by
div.formula: δ i n , i = 1, 2, . . . , n. Denote D := {0, 1}, ∆n = {δ i n | i = 1, 2, . . . , n}, ∆ := ∆2. D n := D × • • • × D n and ∆ n := ∆ × • • • × ∆ n are Cartesian products. A matrix L ∈ Mn×r is called a logical matrix if L can be rewritten as L = [ δ i 1 n δ i 2 n • • • δ ir n ]
div.p: , which is denoted as L = δn [i1 i2 • • • ir] for simpler notation. Coli(L) represents the i-th column of L. Denote by Ln×r the set of n × r logical matrices. W [m,n] represents an mn × mn swap matrix defined in [8], [9]. 1n (0n) is a column vector in R n with all of its elements being 1 (0). diag(M1, M2, . . . , Mn) represents a diagonal matrix with its i-th diagonal as Mi, i = 1, 2, . . . , n. For a matrix A ∈ Mn×m, A << (>>, ≤≤, ≥≥) 0 means that every element of A is negative (positive, nonpositive, nonnegative). Denote by M N the STP of matrices M ∈ M a×b and N ∈ M c×d , which can be referred to [8], [9] for details.

div.head: II. PRELIMINARIES AND SYSTEM DESCRIPTION
div.p: In this section, some necessary preliminaries of STP and system descriptions are introduced.

A bijection σ from D to ∆ can be defined as σ(1) = δ 1 2 and σ(0) = δ 2 2 . Then 1 and 0 are regarded to be equivalent to δ 1 2 and δ 2 2 , respectively. Therefore Boolean variables, as well as Boolean functions, taking value 1 or 0, can be considered in ∆ and said to be expressed in their vector forms. Then, by STP, the following lemma is presented, which is overwhelmingly important to convert BNs into the same form as linear systems.
div.formula: Lemma 1. [8] Let f (x1, x2, . . . , xn) ∈ ∆ be an n-ary Boolean function with xi ∈ ∆, i = 1, 2, . . . , n. Then, there exists a unique logical matrix M f ∈ L2×2n satisfying f (x1, x2, . . . , xn) = M f x, (1
where x = n i=1 xi := x1 x2 • • • xn. Here, M f ∈ L2×2n is called the structure matrix of f .
div.p: As is well known, the STP of matrices becomes exactly the conventional matrix product if b = c. So throughout the paper, the symbol " " will be omitted if no confusion can arise. In the following, the model of BNs with Markovian jump parameters is first presented and then converted into an algebraic form as Markovian jump linear systems.
Consider a BN with n nodes and s updated rules for every node as follows:
div.formula: where xi(k) ∈ D, f θ(k) i : D n → D is a Boolean function, i = 1,
pij = Pr{θ(k + 1) = j|θ(k) = i},(3)
div.p: where pij ≥ 0 for i, j ∈ S and ∑ s j=1 pij = 1 for any i ∈ S. As known, the stationary distribution and the positive recurrent state of a Markov process are of great significance. Therefore, it is convenient to assume that Markov process {θ(k), k ≥ 0} is ergodic, ensuring that {θ(k), k ≥ 0} admits a unique stationary distribution, and each state of the Markov process is reachable from any other state in S.

A BN is said to be globally stable at Xe = (x e 1 , x e 2 , . . . , x e n ) ∈ D n if for any initial value, the state converges to Xe. Taking Markovian jump parameters into consideration, we present the exact definition of global stability in stochastic sense for (2) as follows.

div.head: Definition 1. Stochastic BN (2) is said to be globally stable at Xe ∈ D n in stochastic sense if for any initial value and any initial distribution of θ(k), lim k→∞ E{X(k)|X(0), θ(0)} = Xe.
div.p: Just as in the case of deterministic BNs, Xe can be assumed to be Xe = (0, 0, . . . , 0) without loss of generality, otherwise, a coordinate transformation [9] can be used to guarantee this assumption.

In what follows, network ( 2) is converted into an algebraic form as Markovian jump linear systems. Consider the vector form of Boolean variable xi and Boolean function f j i , still denoted by xi and f j i , respectively, in order to avoid redundancy, i = 1, 2, . . . , n, j = 1, 2, . . . , s. Then, By Lemma 1, the algebraic equivalent form of ( 2) is obtained as follows

div.head: Definition 2. Stochastic BN (2) is said to be globally stable at Xe ∈ D n in stochastic sense if for any initial value and any initial distribution of
div.formula: θ(k), lim k→∞ E{x(k)|x(0), θ(0)} = δ 2 n 2 n .

div.p: Remark 1. In Reference [35], the authors investigated stochastic global stability of BNs under any Markovian switching signal. This problem is always suitable for the case where the switching mechanism is either unknown or too complicated to be useful in stability analysis. When the considered networks are not stochastically globally stable under arbitrary Markovian switching signal, the problem becomes what we mainly focus on in this paper, which is more practical and cannot be tackled by the approach proposed in [35].
From the proof of Theorem 1, the following necessary condition of stochastic global stability is obvious.

div.head: Corollary 1. If stochastic BN (4) is globally stable at
div.formula: xe = δ 2 n 2 n
div.p: in stochastic sense, then all the sub-networks have a common fixed point xe.

On the other hand, it is well known that the Lyapunov function plays an important role in stability analysis and controller design for ordinary dynamic systems. Motivated by Lyapunov function for deterministic BNs [38] and some results about Markovian jump linear systems [41], the definition of Lyapunov function for stochastic BN (4) can be given as follows.
div.formula: Definition 3. A stochastic function V : ∆2n × S → R is called a Lyapunov function for stochastic BN (4), if (i) V (x, θ) > 0, ∀ x ̸ = xe, ∀ θ ∈ S, and V (xe, θ) = 0, ∀ θ ∈ S; (ii) along the trajectories of stochastic BN (4) and Markov process θ(k), ∆V (x(k), θ(k)) := E{V (x(k + 1), θ(k + 1))|x(k), θ(k)}-V (x(k), θ(k)) < 0, ∀ x(k) ̸ = xe, ∀ θ(k) ∈ S, and ∆V (xe, θ(k)) = 0, ∀ θ(k) ∈ S.
div.p: Actually, if BN (4) has a Lyapunov function defined in Definition 3, then BN ( 4) is stochastically globally stable, which can be referred as Lyapunov theorem of stochastic BNs. However, what is more important is how to construct a Lyapunov function for BN (4).
Consider the following function
div.formula: V (x(k), θ(k)) = λ T θ(k) x(k), (15
div.p: where θ(k) ∈ S and λi ∈ R 2 n , i = 1, 2, . . . , s.
div.formula: If λi ∈ R 2 n
div.p: , i = 1, 2, . . . , s, satisfy ( 9)-( 12), then we prove that V (x(k), θ(k)) in ( 15) is a Lyapunpv function for BN (4) next. Obviously, it is easy to obtain that condition (i) of Definition 3 holds from ( 9) and (10). Assume that the mode at time k is i, i.e., θ(k) = i, then the network will jump to another mode θ(k + 1) = j at time k + 1 with probability pij. Thus, along the trajectories of stochastic BN (4), one has
div.formula: ∆V (x(k), i) = E{λ T θ(k+1) x(k + 1)|x(k), θ(k) = i} -λ T i x(k) = ( s ∑ j=1 pijλ T j F i -λ T i ) x(k).
div.p: Then condition (ii) of Definition 3 is satisfied by ( 9), ( 11) and ( 12). Therefore, one form of the stochastic Lyapunov function for stochastic BN (4) can be chosen as (15) and conditions ( 9)-( 12) can be regarded as the Lyapunov stability criterion of stochastic BN ( 2) or ( 4). On the other hand, since the result in Theorem 1 is presented as a necessary and sufficient condition, one can also claim that if BN ( 4) is stochastically globally stable, then there always exists a Lypunov function for BN (4) in the form of (15). With the above analysis, it is easy to have the following result.
Theorem 2. Stochastic BN ( 4) is globally stable at xe = δ 2 n 2 n in stochastic sense if and only if stochastic BN (4) has a Lyapunov function defined as in Definition 3.

Remark 2. When switching signal θ(k) ≡ 1, network (2) becomes a deterministic BN and the above results degenerate to the case of deterministic BN, which is coincident with that in [38]. Therefore, the results can be considered as an extension of [38] and also present a more convenient way to construct a Lyapunov function.

Then the l1 gain problem is formulated as follows.

l1 gain problem: For two given nonnegative weighting vectors ξ ∈ R 2 p , η ∈ R 2 m and a scalar γ > 0, find conditions under which network (17) is globally stable at xe = δ 2 n 2 n in stochastic sense when v(k) ≡ δ 2 m 2 m and the l1 gain of stochastic network (17) is no more than γ, that is,
div.formula: ) Partition F θ(k) as F θ(k) = [F θ(k) (1) F θ(k) (2) • • • F θ(k) (2 m ) ] where F θ(k) (i) ∈ L2n×2n , i = 1, 2, . . . , 2 m . Denote D 2 m ,2 n f = I2m ⊗ 1 T 2 n and D 2 m ,2 n r = 1 T 2 m ⊗ I2n , then D 2 m ,2 n f v(k)x(k) = v(k) and D 2 m ,2 n r v(k)x(k) = x(k).

div.p: Proof. Defining a Lyapunov function as in (15), where λi ∈ R 2 n , i ∈ S satisfy conditions (20)- (24), one gets that network (17) is stochastically globally stable when v(k) ≡ δ 2 m 2 m from Theorem 1. In addition,

div.formula: x(0) = δ 2 n 2 n , K ∑ k=0 ξ T E{y(k)} -γ K ∑ k=0 η T E{v(k)} ≤ -E{V (x(K + 1), θ(K + 1))|x(0), θ(0)} ≤ 0. Let K → ∞, then ∞ ∑ k=0 ξ T E{y(k)} ≤ γ ∞ ∑ k=0 η T E{v(k)}.
div.p: The proof is thus completed.

Remark 3. When switching signal θ(k) ≡ 1, stochastic BN (17) becomes a deterministic disturbed BN which is considered in [39]. Then Theorem 3 degenerates to that for deterministic disturbed BNs, which includes some results in [39] as a special case. Therefore, the obtained result in Section IV can be regarded as an extension of that in [39]. In [42], the authors discussed Markovian jump positive linear systems, which are different from the systems considered in this section. Moreover, the derivations in this paper are totally different from that in [42] because of the finite state space and the STP. But the definition of l1 gain is consistent with that in [42], which shows that l1 gain in this paper is well defined.

Remark 4. In the research of BNs or stochastic BNs, the computational complexity is the most challenging issue and in general NPhard [43]. The computation time increases exponentially with the number of state variables.

div.head: V. EXAMPLES
div.p: Example 1. Consider a network motivated from a simple expression of an apoptosis network [44] with Markovian jump parameters: expresses cell survival, which is a desirable target, then stochastic global stability of (25) Therefore, it follows from Theorem 1 that network (25) is globally stable at xe = δ 8 8 in stochastic sense. The Markovian switching signal and state trajectory under the initial condition x(0) = δ 2 8 are shown in Figures 1 and2, respectively. Therefore, it follows from Theorem 3 that network ( 26) is stochastically globally stable when v(k) ≡ δ 2 2 and has the l1 gain no more than γ = 0.8. In fact, given the external disturbance from time 0 to time 20 randomly as δ 2 2 , δ

div.head: Example 2. Consider that network (25) is interfered by external disturbances and is expressed as follows
div.formula: ∑ ∞ k=0 η T v(k) = 2.8, which yields that ∑ ∞ k=0 ξ T y(k) ≤ γ ∑ ∞ k=0 η T v(k).

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: Stability and l1 gain of BNs with Markovian jump parameters, which can be regarded as an extension of deterministic switching BNs and probabilistic BNs, have been analyzed in this paper. A necessary and sufficient condition for stochastic global stability of Markovian switching BNs has been obtained based on the STP and some results of linear positive systems. It is also shown that the condition can be described in terms of Lyapunov functions. Then, the l1 gain has been proposed to evaluate the performance of stochastic BNs with external disturbances. The results derived in this paper are more general and can be regraded as extensions of some existing ones. Future work of interest is to consider some control problems for BNs with Markovian jump parameters.
